docs.lead_paragraph: Pauline Bracken got home last Sunday to find a long message on her answering machine that began: ''Hello, this is Barbara Bush. I'm calling to tell you about my son George W.'s plan to protect Social Security.'' Mrs. Bracken, 70, a retired cigar worker in Tampa who has little other income besides her Social Security checks, said she smiled to herself as she listened and wished that her husband, who died last year, had been around to share a laugh about it. Then she erased the message and went about her business.

headline.main: A New Respect for Age in Florida

docs.abstract: Gov George W Bush and Vice Pres Al Gore are running neck and neck in Florida, largest state still in contention with 25 electoral votes; both are hotly pursuing retirees as small shift of votes from age group can mean difference between winning and losing; are unlikely to swing many votes with appeals to seniors on matters like Social Security and Medicare as many show little inclination to vote as bloc based on self interest; elderly voters say Bush and Gore plans for Social Security and Medicare have left them more confused than comforted; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Pauline Bracken got home last Sunday to find a long message on her answering machine that began: ''Hello, this is Barbara Bush. I'm calling to tell you about my son George W.'s plan to protect Social Security.''    Mrs. Bracken, 70, a retired cigar...

docs.lead_paragraph: In Scranton, Pa., the Business Roundtable's newborn babies are fighting the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s kindly pharmacist. The National Republican Congressional Committee is represented by a Sherlock Holmes impersonator. The United States Chamber of Commerce features an elderly consumer picking up medicine (but not from the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s druggist). And the Sierra Club is providing a soothing interlude for voters with pristine streams and forests. Every now and then, the candidates in Pennsylvania's 10th Congressional District muscle their way onto the television screens, promising jobs or drug benefits or better schools. But the two men -- Representative Donald L. Sherwood, a freshman Republican, and Patrick Casey, his Democratic challenger -- seem like afterthoughts in a prime example of special interests taking over the local airwaves in the national battle for control of Congress.
docs.abstract: Election campaign in Pennsylvania's 10th Congressional District between freshman Republican Repr Donald L Sherwood and Democratic challenger Patrick Casey is rife with ads paid for by special interests; candidates' own ads seem almost like afterthought; contest is reportedly among top five in country for use of interest group ads; photos (M)
docs.snippet: In Scranton, Pa., the Business Roundtable's newborn babies are fighting the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s kindly pharmacist. The National Republican Congressional Committee is represented by a Sherlock Holmes impersonator. The United States Chamber of Commerce...

docs.lead_paragraph: To this day, puzzling questions hover over Hillary Rodham Clinton's effort to remake the nation's health care system in 1993 and 1994, the most ambitious project of her public life. Mrs. Clinton mastered the complexities of health insurance, and she dazzled Congress with her command of facts and figures. But, even her allies say, she seemed to have a deaf ear for the politics of the issue in Congress.

headline.main: For Mrs. Clinton, Health Plan Left Lessons and Questions

docs.abstract: Puzzling questions still hover over Hillary Rodham Clinton's unsuccessful effort to remake nation's health care system in 1993 and 1994, most ambitious project of her public life; aides say she seemed to have had deaf ear for politics of issue in Congress, even though she mastered complexities of health insurance and dazzled lawmakers with her command of facts and figures; say she disregarded early warnings that her plan was headed for trouble on Capitol Hill, and plowed ahead showing little knack for compromise that is often soul of legislator's art; experience has become relevant in her campaign for US Senate from New York; she acknowledges learning important lessons from debacle, including need to pursue grand goals by incremental steps; says she is applying lessons to Senate race; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Israeli Sees Halt in Talks As Violence Flares Anew Prime Minister Ehud Barak said he was prepared to take an indefinite ''timeout'' from the Israeli-Palestinian peace effort. The announcement followed the deaths of 10 Palestinians in clashes at Israeli checkpoints in the West Bank. The violence, coming despite an internationally brokered truce agreement early in the week, occurred on the eve of a summit meeting of Arab leaders. A1 Secretary General Kofi Annan addressed the General Assembly before it adopted a nonbinding resolution condemning Israel for ''excessive use of force'' against Palestinians but also supporting both sides' returning to the negotiating table. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: The Texas commissioner of health, whose public comments had become a embarrassment for Gov. George W. Bush, was placed on an indefinite leave of absence today. The decision to remove the commissioner, Dr. William R. Archer III, came from the state's commissioner of health and human services, Don A. Gilbert, but there was little doubt that Mr. Bush had played a role.

headline.main: Official Who Embarrassed Bush Is Removed

docs.lead_paragraph: With the Democrats running new commercials attacking his Social Security plan, Gov. George W. Bush struck back hard yesterday, contending that Vice President Al Gore was pitting ''grandparents against grandchildren'' for political gain. Campaigning at a tool factory outside Detroit, Mr. Bush said Mr. Gore ''leads the party of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, but the only thing he has to offer is fear itself.'' In a speech laced with some of his strongest broadsides in the campaign so far, he went on to accuse the vice president of being irresponsible and not facing up to the fiscal problems that Social Security will encounter in coming years.

headline.main: After Attacks, Bush Strikes Back Hard in Defense of His Social Security Proposal

docs.abstract: Gov George W Bush, campaigning in Michigan, strikes back at Democrats' new commercials attacking his Social Security plan; contends that Vice Pres Al Gore is pitting 'grandparents against grandchildren' for political gain; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A Senseless Health Deduction'' (editorial, Oct. 14): For two years, the American Medical Association has strongly supported using refundable tax credits to expand health insurance coverage to the uninsured. Simulations conducted by our Center for Health Policy Research show that providing lower-income individuals with tax credits large enough to cover all or most of their health insurance premiums, combined with increased enrollment of those eligible for Medicaid and the state Children's Health Insurance Program, will get us very close to providing health care coverage for all Americans. Several bipartisan bills have focused on tax credits to expand coverage. We are committed to working with the sponsors of these bills and other lawmakers to make universal coverage a reality in the next Congress. RANDOLPH D. SMOAK, M.D. President American Medical Association Orangeburg, S.C., Oct. 18, 2000

headline.main: A Republican Plan For Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare premiums will rise nearly 10 percent next year, to $50 a month, and Social Security checks will grow by 3.5 percent, to cover increases in the cost of living, the government said today. The cost-of-living adjustment in Social Security will be the largest since 1992.

headline.main: Medicare Premiums and Social Security Will Rise

docs.abstract: Medicare premiums will rise nearly 10 percent next year, to $50 a month, and Social Security checks will grow by 3.5 percent, to cover increases in cost of living; Medicare premiums, which are ordinarily deducted from Social Security checks, will rise $4.50 a month, while average Social Security benefit will increase by $29 a month (M)
